34.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
on this week's show, one challenge, at two

40.text:
ends of the country, 3 species and a 4 wheel
drive Ferrari.

63.text:
Let's start with the challenge. The Mcnab
for the modern Fieldsports enthusiast the

68.text:
Mcnab has evolved into the most challenging
sporting quest in the world. To catch a salmon,

73.text:
to shoot a grouse and to stalk a stag. From
the wilds of Cornwall to the far north of

80.text:
Scotland. The UK offers fantastic sport from
tip to toe. So why limit Mcnab to a single

85.text:
estate and a single day when you can have
it all. 3 species the red stag, red grouse

94.text:
and atlantic salmon are the ultimate in sporting
quarry. So we are heading as far south as

99.text:
possible to bag our stag, up to the Yorkshire
moors for our red grouse and then on up to

104.text:
the river Thurso, just a few miles from John
O' Groats to try and hook our salmon and to

108.text:
make things even more difficult, I have never
shot grouse and I have never used a salmon

112.text:
rod before in my life. Finally 4, the Ferrari
4. The FF this piece of automotive exotica

121.text:
has a 6.3 litre V12 engine, produces 650 horse
power. It can do 0 - 60 in 3.5 seconds and

128.text:
has a top speed of 208 miles an hour. It is
a 4

131.text:
seater, it's 4 wheel drive and best of all
it has plenty of room in the back for your

136.text:
guns and gear. The price of perfection on
the other hand £272,000.

144.text:
We've got three days and 1500 miles to cover
to complete the Ferrari Macnab. So as much

154.text:
fun as it has been, we must leave the sand,
sea and a seasonal tourist fest in Padstow

158.text:
and get some rest, because tomorrow morning
the clock starts ticking and we have an early

162.text:
start ahead of us to give us the best chance
of a Cornish stag.

168.text:
After a sleepless night we swap the Ferrari
for a 4x4 with ground clearnace and head off

172.text:
with professional stalker Scott Milne - In
the vehicle I put my request in..

180.text:
A pricket would be perfect. A little cull
animal....would be absolutely ideal.

187.text: But that never seems to happen does it?

189.text:
Great, oh well let's hope the gods are with
us because blanking here will really ruin

193.text:
With the full moon lending a helping hand
Scott spots some reds deep in the valley - He

197.text:
takes us through fields and sets me up in
a high seat with a block of woods to my left

201.text:
- what he's hoping is the animals will pass
below us as they return from feeding. However,

207.text:
as the lights get switched on we see thick
fog has settled all through the valley.

211.text:
No joy this morning. There is quite a bit
of fog in the bottom valley and Scott thinks

220.text:
that the animals have probably moved back
from the open fields where we first spotted

223.text:
them this morning into the cover of the woods
without us being able to see them through

227.text:
the fog. But we saw a couple of animals out
on the far hill. We have heard a couple of

234.text:
stags roaring in the woods. So what we are
going to do is drop the rifle back to the

239.text:
truck and we are going to go and have a sneak
through the woods and see if we can come across

243.text:
a few deer. See them in action. We are not
allowed to shoot in that particular block

252.text:
I'm keen to learn more about the red deer,
I've only ever stalked hinds in Cumbria, I've

257.text:
never experienced the rut with it's sights,
sounds and smell.

260.text:
We can smell a stag which has just walked
by. Really strong musky smell.

266.text:
It is almost like.. you can be like a German
Pointer, you can be walking through the woods

273.text:
We can't see the stag but you can see the
damage he's doing all around us and we can't

277.text:
blame this inquisitive roe deer for it...
it's all reds.

279.text:
There is a lot of light coming in as you can
see there is just nothing that hasn't been

283.text:
eaten by the deer. There is a real heavy population
of red deer in here. The holly bushes are

288.text:
moulded like somebody comes in and prunes
them by night.

291.text:
We have got some over here that are just a
few inches high

295.text:
Every time any young shoots grow they nibble
them off and the browse line you can tell

296.text: it is red deer in here.

297.text:
You can see how high the line is through the
trees.

298.text:
The ivy everything is all head height. We
can physically look through the trees. If

299.text:
you had to get down onto your knees to look
you know you have roe deer or fallow deer.

308.text:
But when you can physically look stood up
you know it has to be a deer 4 foot to the

317.text:
As we get to the bottom of the valley we here
another roar - and like sailors being drawn

322.text:
to the Siren's call we head in his direction
- Scott takes us through this lot and I try

326.text:
not to think about the Ferrari's pristine
leather interior.!

330.text:
Rising up the other side we know we're getting
closer. If my heart was pounding already thanks

335.text: to Scotts swamp tour it certainly is now.

343.text:
We continue to walk through the wood - there's
a glimpse of some hinds but that's all -

348.text:
We head back and consider our options - My
fantasy scenario was that I'd be on the road

352.text:
heading to Yorkshire by lunchtime but that
isn't going to happen and an evening stalk

356.text:
would really muck up our plans..or at least
any chance of getting our heads down tonight.

362.text:
As well as embracing the finest sport Britain
has to offer on our coast to coast tour it'll

366.text:
will also allow us to sample some of the local
delicacies -

369.text:
Just sampling the millionaire lifestyle, the
glamour of the job, sitting in a Tesco's car

374.text:
park here, Eating a warm Cornish pasty. Rock
and roll.

378.text:
After seeking some advice from apollo the
German pointer we hit on a compromise - It's

382.text:
still early, about 2, but Scott controls deer
on a plantation near a stately home and he

387.text: reckons our best bet is to head over there.

390.text:
It's very different terrain from this morning
- not that I' complaining, and within ten

394.text:
minutes a older red calf is browsing on the
ride infront of us. He hasn't clocked us and

399.text:
it is a good job because at this angle neither
Scott or I can make out if he's male or female.

404.text: Not at the moment. It is about 96 metres.

407.text:
I keep my Blaser R8 rifle and Zeiss Duralyt
scope combo trained on it.

411.text:
Definitely got a black belly and yes there
is a pizzle. In your own time, whenever you

418.text: are happy. It is a safe shot.

420.text:
Scott eventually gives me the nod - he's sure
it's a stag calf and so am I. I just need

425.text: to let him get into a safe shooting position.

434.text:
He's hit and jumps into the cover...thankfully
it doesn't take long for apollo to find the

439.text:
It is not quite the roaring beast we were
pursuing earlier. To be honest with time pressure

445.text:
we are on when Scott said he had spotted a
stag calf, it didn't take very long to make

450.text:
an executive decision that it might be a suitable
choice today. Especially in this area, Scott

455.text:
was explaining the deer do a lot of damage
to a nearby stately home garden and they have

461.text: quite a strong cull policy. Yes quite pleased.

466.text:
Quite pleased ...with a hint of relief mixed
in there too - Scott asks if we want to take

471.text:
some venison with us?..it's tempting, but
we're a bit short of space..which is one of

476.text:
the reasons I asked if Open Season could lend
me a Blaser rifle which breaks down neatly

479.text:
to a ferrari friendly size. The saddle mounts
for the Zeiss scope allowed us to zero the

485.text:
rifle at home, break it down and then rebuild
it for our two outings - it's quite a feat

489.text: of engineering especially as it did the job.

494.text:
Before we leave I ask Scott about some of
the big old boys he gets down here.

498.text: Let's lift this up and have a look at it.

499.text:
This is one of my little ones I knocked over.
The only reason I shot it. It had a real bad

505.text:
broken leg after the rut. In the rut they
rut so hard. They push hinds and with the

510.text:
stone walls we have got and the big rocks
they just put their body on the line and this

515.text:
poor guy smashed his front leg really badly.
He was never going to recover from it so I

519.text:
let him pass his genes on and knocked him
over at the end of the rut. Done him a favour

524.text:
really. But he was still coming up about a
9 year old stag. He is 19 points. That is

530.text:
the sort of calibre we get and may be that
one we heard roaring this morning was of this

536.text:
I am kind of pleased in a way. We have mission
accomplished today and for me this is something

541.text:
to come back for another day. Something to
aspire to in the future. So thanks so much

548.text: Job jobbed. We are going to hit the road.

554.text:
On leaving Cornwall we're still on course
for the Ferrari Macnab and hopefully a decent

560.text:
Day one drawing to a close and stag, after
a fashion, in the bag. I have to say I am

569.text:
really relieved that we managed to get something
today. There was quite a lot riding on the

573.text:
first day if we had failed today it throws
the whole story into turmoil trying to sort

580.text:
out plan B and everything and I didn't sleep
much last night. I think I got about an hours

585.text:
kip, I was just worried about how it was going
to go. Scott was absolutely brilliant, a pleasure

592.text:
to talk to. So knowledgeable about his deer.
So passionate about his stalking. A real education

598.text:
just to walk in the woods with him. I am pleased
for him as well as for us because he tried

604.text:
so hard to make sure he got us our deer. And
to get one on the deck I think both he and

610.text:
I would have liked a slightly larger one,
but I am no trophy hunter and we have helped

615.text:
him with his cull plan. Management is the
big thing for Scott so really, really pleased

620.text:
with that. We have got a couple hundred miles
to go now until our stop over for the night.

628.text: Normally that would be a bit

629.text:
of a chore, but in this thing I think it is
going to be a bit of a pleasure.

648.text:
Our resting place is a hotel just outide Birmingham
- We need to be at the grouse moor for about

654.text: 0730 so it's another early start ahead.

656.text:
Morning, day 2, about 4.30am in a car park
near Birmingham, having just managed to wrestle

664.text:
contact lenses into eyes drier than the Sahara.
We have got about another 100 miles to do

670.text:
this morning. So we had best crack on, but
as you can see I have got my shooting best

675.text:
on today. I would normally reserve a tie for
court appearances and job interviews. Hopefully

679.text: neither of those will result from this trip.

682.text:
Even if the guests at the hotel didn't request
a wake-up call they certainly get one.

699.text:
We start making our way north - eventually
the traffic evaporates and we have our first

717.text:
chance to burn some fossil fuel. Then the
rainbow appears and it's on with the brakes

738.text:
for a photo opportunity in this stunning part
of the country..

747.text:
Back to the job in hand and we need a grouse..I've
never shot one so I'm going to need some help

757.text: Got a good morning, but it is breezy.

762.text: What is the plan you have got for us today.

764.text:
Well this morning we are just going to take
a walk through here, through these hillocks.

768.text:
It is quite a good bit of ground for walking
up grouse. Plenty of blinds, plenty of skyline.

772.text:
A good opportunity to come over a ridge and
drop on them.

777.text:
So if it is open moor that is not so good
for walking up.

780.text:
No it is not especially at this time of year.
We are into October now. We have already had

784.text:
5 driven days on the moor. So it is a case
of we need to get into these outside edges

789.text:
now. If we were to go into the middle of the
moor where we have been driving grouse, we

795.text:
And we are going to be shooting over your
dog today.

796.text:
I have got one spaniel with me, but these
grouse in here, just form in a tight line,

803.text:
walking through nice and steady, they should
hopefully get up in front of us and I have

811.text: Fingers crossed. Let's go and have a go.

815.text:
The weather, temperature and terrain are in
complete contrast to our stalking which was

819.text:
only 24 hours ago. It's hard going and unfortunately
the birds are lifting well before we're in

825.text:
range. Then I get my chance - and the birds
continue on their flight path. It's a big

830.text:
blow - I just sense the opportunities are
going to be few and far between and I need

834.text:
to put all my hours watching Andy Crow into
practice.

838.text:
The grouse are really flighty. We have had
one opportunity which I have fluffed. Any

844.text:
advice on shot placement and what I should
be looking at. Or just get onto them as quick

848.text:
As quick as you can. Ready at all times. Any
time the grouse can get up and you need to

850.text:
be on to them. As you saw really fast wing
beat. They are out of range in no time. Get

858.text:
straight onto them swing through, best of
luck.

864.text:
We pack up and head across to another part
of the moor - the weather is even worse over

868.text:
here and I'm glad I forced those in contact
lenses.This isn't the weather for glasses

875.text:
Then I get my second chance and we watch --- and
we watch and we keep watching until ...

885.text:
Right let's do a bit of a walk round here
and come round into that and we can pick it

908.text:
We work our way around and back but there
isn't a second chance. All I really want to

916.text:
The wind is unbelievable as you can see. Raining
side ways. I don't know who was more surprised

922.text:
me or the grouse or Jim that the bird was
hit. And everybody the bird, the dog, me and

929.text:
mostly Jim, were praying that he picks it
up and accomplished part 2.#

935.text:
After 10 nail bitting minutes we have a grouse
and even though some purits might say I need

940.text:
a brace - I don't care - I never specified
bags just species and this one counts - alot.

947.text:
I was getting a bit worried. I am going to
give your dog a kiss in a minute. I love that

957.text:
As I said before this road trip can present
opportunities to tantilise taste buds and

963.text:
just like the ferrari I need some high octane
fuel to keep me firing on all cylinders. And

968.text:
in this part of the world I know just the
place - and it looks like they're expecting

973.text:
So yesterday I attempted some regional cuisine
and it went pretty badly with our luke warm

978.text:
cheese pasty. We are not going to make the
same mistake twice. So we have come to this

982.text:
fantastic butchers which is in ......just
up the road from the grouse moor and this

990.text:
At this phase of our Ferrari Macnab we've
been joined by Chris Blackburn of UK Gunworks

995.text:
and his friend John Maclean - They're not
just here for the pies although I wouldn't

998.text:
blame them. They've helped arrange grouse
shooting and salmon fishing for the challenge

1002.text:
and most importantly Chris is going to teach
me how to cast.

1007.text:
Refuelled and relishing the fact that we've
bagged our second species it's back at Jims

1011.text:
to take in some breathtaking views and talk
moors.

1015.text:
You were telling us that since you have been
here the last few years you have turned around

1020.text:
the grouse numbers here. How have you done
that and what are the knock on effects of

1027.text:
Yes, the grouse numbers have increased nicely
on this moor. And it is just down to the main

1032.text:
principles of grouse moor management which
are predator control. Foxes, crows, stoats

1037.text:
and weasels throughout the year, but concentrating
more at spring time, the most crucial time

1043.text:
of the year. Habitat management. We have reduced
the grazing on the moor, we have improved

1048.text:
the heather burning and the habitat as you
could see this morning, it is looking good

1053.text:
at the moment. It is. Application of medicated
grit as well that has helped a lot as well.

1057.text:
It allows you to carry a stock of grouse and
you are not building up strongylosis.

1064.text:
Well I have taken one of the moor for you
today. It was pretty tricky conditions. I

1069.text:
imagine that a lot of guns find it pretty
contrasting to your average pheasant shoot

1075.text: if you are not prepared for it.

1076.text:
Well we do get people come who have never
shot grouse before. They might have shot a

1080.text:
lot of pheasants or lot of partridges, but
this is just a whole different kettle of fish

1086.text:
When they get this wind up their tails they
just go don't they?

1088.text: Rather do. They are like rockets.

1090.text:
Well talking about wind getting up their tail
I think we are going to have to do that. So

1094.text:
thanks for your time Jim. We will see you
again.

1105.text:
What a morning, what a great guy and what
an experience. I'm never going to forget my

1110.text:
first grouse...we wend our way though this
beautiful part of the country back to civilisation

1119.text:
- stopping for some super unleaded - suddenly
I feel a little over dressed and I'm in need

1125.text:
of a costume change for the next leg of the
ferrari macnab

1128.text:
So we are heading up from the grouse moor
in Yorkshire towards Scotland. But we have

1132.text:
got a problem, I haven't got any fishing gear.
Hopefully we are going to solve that by paying

1136.text:
a visit to the famous John Norris fishing
super store here in Penrith. Let's go and

1140.text: see a man about a rod.

1146.text:
It's really more than just a shop - and I
am hoping that some fishing expertese/know

1150.text:
how /magic even luck might rub off on me - I'm
no stranger to fishing but I'm really apprehensive

1157.text:
that I'm got make a real cock salmon of this
last part of the challenge.

1160.text:
I have never been salmon fishing in my life
and I need some help.

1162.text: No problem at all - dead easy.

1163.text:
Talk me through the essentials, what do I
need and how to use it.

1167.text:
First thing you need to know is where you
are fishing.

1170.text: Ok we are fishing up on the river Thurso.

1172.text:
So you are going to need a 15 foot salmon
fly rod which is a ......rod. A reel to match

1177.text:
that, balance that up with a fly line, selection
of flies, leading material. You will need

1184.text:
to get kitted out in the right gear, waders,
wading boots, wading jacket, so you are covered

1187.text:
So it is not as simple as a tackle box and
pair of wellies then?

1191.text:
No, no a bit more complicated, but I will
make it as easy as I can for you.

1195.text: Great stuff let's go and have a look.

1199.text:
It does feel very light, but it looks, double
handed is that going to be more complicated

1203.text: for someone like me who has never done it.

1204.text:
No, double handed, it sounds complicated,
but it's a lot easier than it sounds. Easier

1205.text: to cast a double handed than it is a single.

1214.text: Blimey it looks like a winch. Incredibly light.

1219.text:
Light, big..... so you get a very fast rate
of retrieve when you bring your line in.

1225.text: This line perfectly balances with that rod.

1228.text:
So if you get the wrong line your fancy rod
won't work properly anyway.

1231.text:
No, everything has got to match, everything
has got to be well balanced.

1234.text:
What on earth our salmon feeding on if they
are going to take things like this.

1237.text: They aren't in the river feeding.

1238.text:
So that is true salmon don't feed when they
are in fresh water.

1241.text:
No they are not feeding in fresh water at
all. You are just trying to trigger aggression.

1245.text:
My fabulous Mr men booties will have to go
too if I'm going to stand firm on the rocks.

1249.text:
All this amazing help and advice is not helping
the nerves, I always thought we might have

1254.text:
a chance of a deer and a grouse but the salmon...
that's in a different league. And if you want

1259.text:
to know what this fish does to grown men just
look at James' eyes when he answers my next

1265.text: What is it with the salmon.

1266.text:
Salmon is probably the hardest catch, because
they are not feeding in fresh water and they

1270.text:
are probably the hardest fighting fresh water
fish you will find. Once you get that take

1274.text:
from the fish, you will know exactly what
I mean. Your heart stops, the fish takes,

1279.text:
then the fight starts and it is absolutely
phenomenal. The best feeling in the world.

1283.text:
But again they are the hardest fish to catch,
because they are not feeding.

1287.text:
So it is all about the challenge. Not only
is it an incredible fish to fight it is the

1292.text:
challenge actually catching it in the first
place.

1293.text:
Because you can put a lot of hours in for
salmon with not many good results, but when

1298.text:
you do get your results in and you put the
hours in the results are fantastic.

1303.text:
Right - all the gear - and you guessed it
no idea we leave penrith on the last leg of

1308.text:
our journey - and it's a long long way...to
the top of bonnie scotland...

1313.text:
A quick mileage update. We have still got
another 350 miles to go and it is telling

1320.text:
us that it will take about 7.5 hours. Which
means we will probably be rocking into our

1325.text:
accommodation tonight at about midnight. Which
is a pretty long day. But the car so far has

1333.text:
been awesome. It is just eating the miles,
really comfortable, cruises beautifully as

1338.text:
you would expect and there are worse places
to spend 7.5 hours. David's car for starters.

1361.text:
Wednesday morning and the last day of the
Ferrari Macnab - We're staying at the world

1365.text:
famous Ulbster Arms on the banks of The River
Thurso - Before breakfast Chris takes me down

1370.text:
to the bridge for a bit of a pep talk and
to enjoy the views of this famous stretch

1373.text: of water so often enjoyed by Royalty -

1375.text:
And the line will come round onto the dangle
and there is a back eddy where the line will

1380.text:
go slack and the line starts coming towards
you naturally.

1383.text:
There's also some advice from Dougie reid
who has been fishing this water for 40 years...I

1389.text:
then get a crash course in casting - and cue
the Rocky-type monatge of me getting stronger

1396.text:
- casting longer may be not.. lets get on
with it and head to our beat,,, lucky number

1401.text:
We are quite optimistic this morning. The
weather is lovely the water is in great condition

1406.text:
and I think over 20 fish were banked yesterday.
There is quite a lot of positivity. There

1411.text:
was somebody who was fishing this week who
had never fished before and caught their first

1416.text:
salmon. So it can be done. Whether the gods
are smiling on us today we will have to wait

1420.text:
and see, but we are going to give it a good
go.

1422.text:
Although it looks cool we leave the ferrari
plus rod on the bank near the hotel...I wonder

1427.text:
what would happen to it of we did 200mph with
that strapped to the bonnet??!

1432.text:
Like a boxer about to enter the ring - my
trainer and manager man handle me preparing

1436.text:
me for the first round. Tentativley I creep
out into the river - fish are jumping all

1444.text:
around me and within 15 minutes I get a take
- what a moment !! -

1447.text:
Wow........No!.........I just had a take......I
could actually cry now. What if that is it.

1457.text:
What if that is the only fish that comes anywhere
near all day. I am actually shaking.

1470.text:
Despite all the advice to wait when you get
a take my years of trout fishing meant I snatched

1474.text: at the rod - and my salmon has gone....

1475.text:
It is a long way to be here. But it all feels
worth it now even without landing anything.

1484.text:
I think it is a pretty special place to end
the film. I don't know why I am saying that.

1491.text: It is 10 o'clock. Another 7 hours fishing.

1495.text:
Half and hour later Chris shouts to us that
he's in - he thinks it's about 6lbs - what

1500.text:
a moment - it's so exciting - people try for
years to catch salmon...Chris takes it in

1511.text:
I want to weigh it. Cock fish. What did I
say it was, a guess?

1530.text: Hook in the mouth. Hook's out.

1537.text: 4.5 - 5 .....4.5 not a bad guess was it?

1547.text: Can I touch it before it goes back.

1553.text:
Notice the cape on its nose there. That is
where it has been in the river long the cock

1557.text:
fish tend to get a cape, hook. It is bleeding
a little bit, nothing bad. What I will do

1561.text:
is put it in the water. Working it backwards
and forwards to get water through its gills.

1567.text:
And he will let you know when he is ready
to go.

1572.text:
That is what I am doing now. A lot of people
put them back having fought them for 15 to

1576.text:
20 minutes and recover it for 10 seconds and
then let it go because their hands are cold

1589.text:
in the water or something silly. Fish welfare
is the priority. He is ready to go. There

1608.text:
Worth the journey for something like that
then Chris.

1609.text:
Fantastic, absolutely fantastic. We have seen
a lot of fish moving up and you know both

1612.text:
flies are fishing over the top of fish and
you are in with a chance and sure enough Chris

1617.text:
said he has missed one and then 3 casts later,
2 casts later bosh straight in. So fantastic.

1625.text:
First wild salmon I have seen banked. Just
makes me hungry to get involved.

1630.text:
I too head back into the water and a change
of fly - then incredibly - I'm in... This

1637.text:
Coming up stream. My heart is about to come
through the front of my chest here. Have you

1649.text:
noticed how the normal drivel that comes out
of my mouth has stopped.

1653.text:
I'ver never been so focused in all my life.
The guys on the bank want me to describe what's

1659.text: Ooh - feel the tail slap the line can't you?

1664.text:
After 10 minutes of terror Chris nets my fish,
and what a fish ... and I've done it - 3 species

1670.text:
in 3 days, from one end of the country to
the other... in a supercar.

1680.text:
I can't believe it. There we go just in the
bottom of the mouth. Here it is. My first

1688.text:
ever salmon. Here on the river Thurso. Beat
4. The Ferrari Mcnab we have done it, I can't

1698.text:
believe it. 3 days ago didn't give us a hope.
I'll keep hold of it for a while. I think

1713.text:
We see the salmon safely back into the water
- no trophy for me just the memory of a knee

1721.text:
tembling moment that will stay with me for
the rest of my life...something I'll tell

1725.text:
my young son about when he's old enough to
understand.

1728.text:
Relief and torrential rain pour down on me....I
hooked a salmon and now salmon fishing has

1734.text: hooked me - I'm straight back in the river.

1739.text:
For the next few hours Chris, John, David
and I just grin at each other... then Chris

1744.text:
says he has a surprise for me - a chance to
fish on the Thuro's private beat with Head

1748.text:
ghille Dougie Reid - What a privilege and
what a place!

1753.text: So what is a full spey cast then?

1754.text:
Well it's a double spey swing....swing and
swing. But I am only half doing it. I am not

1760.text:
doing it the proper way. Spey fishing is merely
done in the rivers, spey casting.

1765.text:
We are fishing quite a special beat on the
river today.

1768.text:
You are, you are on the private beat. Which
belongs to Lord Thurso. The Queen Mother used

1776.text:
to fish it when she was alive. She came up
here every summer and stayed at Castle of

1780.text:
Mey and the Thurso was her little treat and
she used to love fishing. And Prince Charles

1789.text: It is a beautiful spot isn't it.

1790.text:
It is a lovely spot. The private beat is unique
on the Thurso. The rest of the Thurso is quite

1796.text: open and flat. This bit is lovely.

1800.text:
Dougie is another one who still gets the salmon
shakes after all these years.

1805.text:
It just makes your knees tremble and I still
get that feeling.

1808.text: Even today after all those fish.

1809.text:
Even after all the fish I have caught. I don't
know how many fish I have caught over the

1818.text:
At the begining of the 20th century the river
was damed which meant the water levels and

1822.text:
the fishing could be maintained for longer.
It also meant there was a huge obstacle preventing

1826.text:
the salmon from reaching their spawning grounds,
so a fish ladder was built at the same time.

1831.text:
So these amazing fish have already had to
swim over 20 miles to get from the sea to

1837.text:
here. They get here. They have got the fish
ladders built in here to protect them from

1841.text:
the flow of water and allow them to get up
stream and into the loch. Their journey is

1845.text:
not done here they still have to go all the
way up into the hills behind me to get to

1848.text:
their spawning ground. They are an amazing
fish.

1852.text:
On the way back to beat 4 for a few final
hours fishing we see a scottish red stag - our

1857.text:
cornish red was only 48 hours ago but we've
crammed so much in it feels like a week.

1862.text:
We may have completed THE Ferrari Macnab challenge
but there's somewhere we feel we need to be

1868.text:
in order to complete THE journey - John O'Groats
half an hour north of here. Again there's

1874.text:
a fuel stop to keep the V12 singing along
as we head for the UK's northern coastline.

1888.text:
The weather remains dry and bright, the Ferrari
looks fab next to the famous sign post. I

1894.text:
feel exhausted but so chuffed. So many people
have helped me with this mad event and I still

1899.text: can't believe it has actually worked out.

1901.text:
So here we are John O'Groats, the end of the
line for us after 3 amazing days. We have

1906.text:
done 1500 miles, we got our 3 species. We
have done the Ferrari Mcnab and the best news

1912.text:
of all. I have just been told it is 755 miles
to drive home and I can't wait.

1919.text:
This journey began as a celebration of British
Fieldsports, but it has been so much more

1923.text:
than that. It has been an opportunity to meet
some remarkable people. People that have dedicated

1928.text:
their lives to the preservation, improvement
and management of our most fragile habitats,

1933.text:
from ancient woodland to heather moorland
to the pristine rivers of Scotland. These

1938.text:
people, are the true guardians of our wild
spaces. That they share their knowledge with

1942.text:
such enthusiasm is a gift to all of us. They
deserve our respect, our admiration and our

1948.text:
support... if nothing else to offset the carbon
footprint of this amazing machine.

1954.text:

the usual news and Hunting Youtube, click
